data.name: Binary Object Insertion.
data.description:
When given a sorted array of objects, each of which has a 'value' property, like so: demo = [{value:0},{value:10},{value:11}] and one wishes to insert a new corresponding object into this array, while preserving the sorted nature of it, one might simply demo.push({value:8});
demo.sort(function(a,b){return a.value > b.value}); However, this is a very inefficient method on larger lists. Instead, you should write a method that performs a binary insertion. The way this works is the following: When I am looking for someone named "Oprah" in an alphabetically sorted list of names, I might open it up to the middle. Upon seeing that I'm in the M's, I would then check halfway between my current position and the end. There, I might land in the T's. So I would check halfway between my current position and the middle. And so on, until I find the name I'm looking for. Write a function that works this way. The test case given to you is the only type of test case you'll have; you won't need to sort strings, and they will always be object with a value property.
